page.title: 01The Glynn Valley
page.content: From east to west, the main road (A38) runs into Cornwall along the Glynn Valley, mimicking the Serpentine coarse of the river Fowey: while on the opposite bank, the Paddington to Penzance railway line sweeps along the shoulder of the valley, carried in places, high above the ground on great viaducts. The Glynn Valley is a ribbon of woodland that gives pleasure to the travellers, russet hues of autumn leaves, tinted sunlight in summer and woodland daffodils and blue bells. But it is probably as a mafor thoroughfare that the valley has always had most importance, guarded in ancient times by Largin Castle with its great earth walls and commanding views along the vallye. A public house and an out-of-town shopping centre are the only public establishments in the valley.
